Department of Chemistry Malaviya National Institute of Technology Jaipur Jaipur 302017 India In this report, we present an enhanced Suzuki-Miyaura (SM) cross-coupling reaction catalyzed by a Ni(II) complex coordinated with a N-bound triazolyl-pyridine (tmtp) ligand featuring a pendant tolyloxymethyl group. The N-bound triazolyl-pyridine ligand is chosen for its distinct electronic properties compared to structurally similar "C-bound" triazolyl-pyridine and bipyridyl ligands. The newly synthesized square-planar, diamagnetic nickel complex [Ni(tmtp)2](NO3)2 (1) has been thoroughly characterized using various spectroscopic and spectrometry techniques including 2-D NMR. The developed methodology requires only 2 mol% of catalyst loading and is applicable for aryl-iodide, -chlorides and –bromides. ESI-MS (+) analysis of the reaction mixture at different time intervals revealed the provable catalytic cycle via Ni(0)/Ni(II). Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords N-bound triazolyl-pyridine SM cross coupling reaction Low catalyst loading Felbinac drug molecule Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction One of the most significant reactions in modern chemical synthesis is the Suzuki-Miyaura (SM) cross-coupling reaction [1,2], which is used to synthesize essential CC bonds between aromatic or heterocyclic halide and aryl boronic acid [3–5]. It is extensively employed in the pharmaceutical sector [6], notably in commercializing many FDA-approved medications (Fig. 1 ) [7]. Generally, Pd-based catalysts are used to facilitate such CC bond formation reactions in mild reaction conditions with a generation of relatively less unwanted materials. However, the most expensive component of a palladium-catalyzed SM cross-coupling catalytic process is the palladium metal itself [8–10]. Therefore, the development of an alternative methodology based on a relatively cheap metal like nickel is in high demand. For this purpose, in 2016, Suganthy and co-workers used a benzoyl hydrazone-based Ni(II) octahedral complex as a catalyst in SM cross-coupling reaction to produce bi-phenyl derivatives [11]. In 2019, Key and co-workers used a heterogeneous Ni(II) catalyst to produce bi-phenyl derivatives where aryl iodides along with phenylboronic acids were used as the coupling partners [catalyst: (100 mg), base: K3PO4, solvent: dioxane, time: 24 h, 115 °C] [12]. In the same year, Florian and co-workers used [(dcpp)Ni(ɳ2-arene)] (dcpp: dicyclo phosphene propane) complex to produce bi-phenyl derivatives [catalyst: 3.0 mol%, base: K3PO4, solvent: dioxane/H2O, time: 16 h, 80 °C] [13]. In 2022, Lee and team utilized Ni(II) catalyst containing a tridentate ONC ligand [catalyst: 3.0 mol%, base: K3PO4.H2O, solvent: toluene, 100 °C, time: 4 h] in SM cross-coupling reaction to furnish bi-phenyl derivatives with generally electron-withdrawing aryl chlorides [14]. In the same year, Guo and team used a Ni(II) catalyst along with DPPB [DPPB = 1,4-bis(diphenylphosphino)butane] as a supporting ligand and an amine base to produce bi-phenyl derivatives [15]. Upon reviewing the aforementioned literature, it becomes evident that the majority of the existing techniques face challenges such as excessive catalyst usage, a restricted range of applicable substrates, and the intricate synthesis of the catalysts involved. In 2018, Elumalai and his group exploited a Ni(COD)2 catalyst supported by a Metal-organic framework (MOF) UiO-66 with “C-bound” triazole containing moiety for the synthesis of bi-phenyl derivatives via SM cross-coupling reaction [catalyst: 3.0 mol%, base: K2CO3, solvent: ACN, additives: PPh3, time: 12 h, 65 °C] [16]. A structurally closely related but electronically different N-bound triazolyl pyridine ligand-supported Ni(II) complex may show an outstanding catalytic SM cross-coupling reaction. This hypothesis comes from our recent observation of a catalytic SM cross-coupling reaction catalyzed by a mononuclear Pd(II) complex supported by bis(bidentate) N-bound triazolyl-pyridine ligand on a phthalic acid platform [17]. Here, it was proposed that the coordination of two electron-rich N3 nitrogen from two separate triazole rings makes the palladium center relatively more electron rich compared to similar other neutral N-donor ligands which facilitated the first oxidative addition reaction during the catalytic cycle, which ultimately improved the activity of the described catalyst. However, these N-bound isomers are considerably rare within the triazolyl pyridine ligand family (Fig. 2 ) [18]. This rarity is likely due to the synthetic challenges posed by the ring-chain tautomerism between 2-azidopyridine and pyrido tetrazole in solution [19,20]. We are interested in the catalytic activity of the transition metal complexes supported by relatively electron-rich N-bound triazolyl-pyridine ligand (Fig. 3 ). In this study, we report the synthesis of a new Ni(II) complex co-ordinated with N-bound triazolyl-pyridine ligands that shows very good catalytic capabilities in SM cross-coupling reactions involving aryl chlorides/bromides/iodides with only 2 mol% catalyst loading. Remarkably, the current Ni(II) complex demonstrates better catalytic performance than previously known Ni(II) catalysts for the same reaction (Table 1 , ESI). 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis of nickel complex Recently, we introduced bis(bidentate) N-bound triazolyl-pyridine [bptmp] ligand on a phthalic acid platform for the preparation of an unusually coordinated Pd(II) complex that shows exceptional recyclable catalytic activity for SM coupling reaction [17]. Surprisingly, the analogous Ni(II) complex supported by the same [bptmp] ligand could not be synthesized after several attempts. We thought to apply a relatively flexible ligand system compared to [bptmp] keeping the core N-bound triazolyl-pyridine group intact. Here, we preferentially used our previously reported [tmtp] [21] ligand in which along with the N-bound triazolyl-pyridine chelate group a pendant O-tolyl group is also attached to the triazole moiety to further influence its electronic properties. The targeted novel Ni(II) complex was synthesized following Scheme 1 . To synthesize Ni(II) complexes of the ‘tmtp’ ligand, ‘tmtp’ was reacted with NiCl2 in both 1:1 and 2:1 ligand-metal ratio in acetonitrile. However, none of those reactions were clean enough to isolate the corresponding complexes in pure form. Importantly, when the same reaction was carried out in CH3CN at room temperature with Ni(NO3)2•6H2O in a 2:1 ligand-metal ratio, the corresponding Ni(II) complex formed in high yield (63 %) (Scheme 1). After successful synthesis of the Ni-tmtp complex, its solubility was tested in different solvents and found that the isolated complex is fully soluble in solvents like acetonitrile, DMSO, DMF, and partially soluble in MeOH, CHCl3, DCM. Due to the strong field nature of the N-bound triazolyl-pyridine and the presence of triazole nitrogen (N2) and pyridine nitrogen in a plane, it was anticipated that the newly formed Ni(II) complex would be of square planar geometry and diamagnetic in nature [22]. The formation of a diamagnetic Ni(II) complex was confirmed from a conventional clear proton NMR spectrum in the range of 1-9 ppm. The Ni(II) complex was characterized through 1H, 13C{1H}, and various 2D NMR spectroscopy in DMSO-d6 and high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS). In the 1H NMR spectrum, the distinct peak corresponding to -CH2 protons was observed at 5.12 ppm, while the peak for the C–H proton of the triazole ring appeared at 8.85 ppm (ESI; Fig. S5). The stacked diagram illustrates the changes in the 1H NMR spectra on moving from the free ligand to the Ni(II) complex (Fig. 4 ), confirms the coordination of the ligand to the Ni(II) center. The ESI (+) mass spectrum of complex-1 shows a peak at m/z = 295.0838, which is assigned for C30H28N8NiO2 2+ [M – 2NO3]2+ ion (ESI; Fig. S9), this supports a 1:2 metal-ligand complexation. In the FT-IR spectra, on moving from the free ligand to the Ni-complex the characteristics triazole peak shifts from 3090 cm-1 to 3106 cm-1 whereas the bending vibration of the C=C bond shifts from 817 cm-1 to 779 cm-1 (ESI; Fig. S12), which is also the support to metal complexation [21]. 2.2 Catalytic reactions The newly synthesized Ni(II) complex (1; 2 mol %) was tested as a catalyst in the SM cross-coupling reaction employing both aryl bromides and chlorides as substrates and found to be active. The reaction involving 4-bromonitrobenzene and phenylboronic acid was used as the standard, with the initial parameters being K2CO3 as a base (3 equiv.) and a reaction duration of 7 h at 100 °C in toluene/H2O (1:0.15) solvent combination. Several reaction conditions were tested to optimize the reaction conditions (as outlined in Table 1). We performed the same reaction with a lower catalyst loading (1; 1.0 mol%) and found a significant decay (approx. 20 %) in the observed yield of the desired product. The inclusion of a small amount of water as an additive appears to expedite the reaction, likely due to the assistance of the added water in activating K2CO3 towards phenylboronic acid, as evidenced by the comparison between [entries 6 and 7] [23]. However, the same reaction produced the desired product in a very low yield (11 %) when carried out in a water medium [entry 12]. Among the range of bases (KO t Bu, DIPEA and K3PO4) commonly utilized in nickel-catalyzed SM cross-coupling reactions, demonstrated effectiveness similar to that of K2CO3 [entries 13, 14, 15]. However, the yield obtained with the amine base trimethylamine (TEA) was moderate [entry 16]. Among all the tested solvent combinations, a toluene-water mixture (1:0.15) emerged as the preferred solvent and proved more effective even compared to ether-based solvents such as dioxane [entry 9] and THF [entry 10]. However, efforts without catalyst loadings led to a trace amount of yield [entry 17]. Based on all the above-mentioned reactions, we established our standard reaction condition based on the one outlined in entry 7 of Table 1. This is to report here that the same reaction can be performed at room temperature employing NiCl2 as a catalyst in a mixture of toluene and a catalytic amount of water (0.25-0.15 mL) in the presence of K2CO3 as a base. However, the conversion is relatively low, as indicated in (Table 1, entry 2-3). A greener solvent ratio [toluene/water: 1/1] did not notably accelerate the reaction at room temperature. However, when the same reaction was performed at 100 °C, the conversion was relatively high but significantly low in comparison to our Ni(II) complex (Table 1, entry 4 vs. entry 7). Performing the same reaction under standard conditions with Ni(NO3)2•6H2O salt led to a comparatively low conversion of the product, as indicated in entry 5. After establishing the optimized reaction conditions, we aimed to assess our catalyst's efficacy across a range of substrates, including aryl halides and aryl boronic acids. Outstanding yields (81–94 %) of various biaryl products were achieved from aryl bromides [4Aa-4Na, 4Bb-4Bd, 4De-4Df, 4Fb-4Ff, 4Oe, 4Pf]. However, when dealing with aryl chlorides, the yield slightly decreases to about 50 % under the optimized conditions [4Aa, 4Ba, 4Da, 4Ga, 4Fa, 4La] (refer to Table 2 ). We have successfully synthesized the biologically significant heterocycle [4Ha] and anti-inflammatory drug Felbinac [4Ma] in high yield using our methodology (Table 2). Until now, our exploration of the substrate scope has primarily focused on varying the aryl halide component while maintaining a constant phenylboronic acid. To assess the versatility of our catalyst with different functionalized boronic acids, we planned to utilize some additional boronic acids: 4-methoxyphenyl, 4-acetyl, 4-nitro, 4-fluoro phenyl boronic acid, which are equipped with electron-donating and withdrawing groups, respectively. We observed that the yield of the biaryl product remains nearly identical when electron-withdrawing groups are present on both the aryl halide and the phenylboronic acid (4De), or if the electron-donating group is attached to the phenylboronic acid while the electron-withdrawing group is attached to the aryl halide (4Df). The exceptional catalytic efficiency of Ni(II) in the SM cross-coupling reaction is attributed to the o-tolyl N-bound triazolyl pyridine ligand framework. We propose that the coordination of the N2 nitrogen of triazole and pyridine nitrogen of the N-bound triazolyl-pyridine ligand with the Ni(II) center enhances its suitability for the oxidative addition of aryl halide, a crucial initial step in the catalytic cycle. Moreover, the specific association of two tmtp ligands and two aryl groups to the nickel center generates sufficient steric to support the reductive elimination in the final step. 3 Mechanism A plausible reaction mechanism has been proposed as depicted in Scheme 2 [15]. In the reaction medium, it is expected that the Ni(II) complex will remain in its characterized square-planar geometry until the addition of aryl-halide and function as the precatalyst. The optimized structure of the Ni-complex (catalyst) is shown in Fig. 5 . The ligands are bound in a bidentate fashion in a square planar geometry which can be attributed to bond angles ∠N1-Ni-N2 = 81.2°, ∠N2-Ni-N3 = 98.2°, ∠N3-Ni-N4 = 81.7° and ∠N4-Ni-N1 = 99.0°. Both the ligands and Ni(II) are situated almost in the same plane having ∠N1-Ni-N3 = 176.6° and ∠N2-Ni-N4 = 177.7°. It is believed that Ni-catalysed cross couplings reaction follows the path similar to Pd-catalysed cross couplings reaction [24,25]. Firstly, precatalyst Ni(II) is reduced to Ni(0) at higher temperature under basic condition [26,27]. Next, the active catalytic Ni(0) complex undergoes oxidative addition (O.A.) with the aryl halide to generate intermediate-A. Next, in the presence of a base, PhB(OH)2 combines with intermediate-A via transmetalation followed by trans-to-cis rearrangements leading to intermediate-B which releases the desired biaryls via reductive elimination (R.E.). We carried out a TEMO (2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinoxyl) mediated radical scavenging experiment to check the radical nature of the catalytic cycle and no significant decrease in yield (77 %) of the biaryl product was observed. This result suggests that the catalytic cycle does not involve a single electron transfer (SET) process neither at the Ni center nor at the ligand center. This excludes the possibility of a Ni(I)/Ni(III) catalytic cycle. Further, to check the homogeneity of the catalytic cycle, we performed the mercury drop test, however, no decrease in the yield of the desired product was observed. Interestingly, ESI-MS (+) studies of the reaction aliquots show the formation of species with molecular ion peak at m/z = 825.1302 (Fig. 7) which exactly matches with the calculated molecular ion of intermediate-A, a Ni(II) species. Having the previous literature knowledge that the reduction of Ni(II) to Ni(0) needs the basic environment and higher temperature [28,29] we proposed a plausible mechanism in Scheme 2. To gain deeper insight into the reaction process, we examined the underlying reaction mechanism. The surface composition of nickel (Ni) species was characterized using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The effectiveness of the XPS technique lies in its sensitivity to the chemical environment of an atom, which significantly influences the measured binding energies (BEs) of core-level electrons-an influence known as the chemical shift [30,31]. In the survey scan XPS spectrum of the pre-catalyst (Fig. 6 a), the Ni 2p core-level signals exhibited two distinct peaks. The Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 peaks appeared at binding energies of 853.2 eV and 870.9 eV, respectively, which are indicative of Ni(II) species [32]. Additionally, satellite peaks were observed at 861.9 eV and 881.4 eV on the higher binding energy sides of the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 regions [33,34]. Upon introducing an aryl halide into the Ni(II) system, an additional small peak corresponding to metallic Ni emerged at 849.1 eV (Fig. 6b), accompanied by Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 peaks at 853.1 eV and 871.3 eV respectively, which confirms the zero-oxidation state of Ni-catalyst [35,36]. 4 Conclusion An improved methodology for the catalytic synthesis of diverse biaryls is reported using a novel Ni(II) complex of an N-bound triazolyl-pyridine ligand. Importantly, in this methodology, aryl chloride and bromides are applied instead of more expensive aryl iodides. The diamagnetic square planar Ni(II) complex was characterized by applying various spectroscopic and spectrometry methods. Mass spectrometry studies of the reaction mixture allowed us to identify the proposed Ni(II) species (intermediate-A) generated during the catalytic pathway. This allowed us to draw a probable Ni(0)-Ni(II) catalytic cycle for the developed methodology. This work represents a step forward in the quest for efficient Ni-catalysis for SM cross-coupling reactions. 4.1 Experimental section All the experiments were carried out under an ambient atmosphere unless otherwise mentioned the use of an inert atmosphere. All the chemicals and solvents were used as received from the suppliers without further purification. Reagents 2-bromopyridine (99 %) and propargyl bromide (87 %) were purchased from Spectrochem, India. Solvents hexane and ethyl acetate were purchased from Finar Limited Company. The SM cross-coupling reactions were performed under an ambient atmosphere. For inert atmosphere reactions, acetonitrile was dried using the conventional method and was distilled before use. Normal (particle size: 100–200 mesh) and flash (particle size: 230–400 mesh) silica gels were used for column chromatography, and they were purchased from Qualigens (India), Spectrochem (India), and Rankem (India). To monitor the progress of chemical reactions, TLC plates covered with silica gel (Kiesel 60-F254, Merck, India) were utilized. UV light was used as the visualizing agent for TLC. All of the solvents were dried and concentrated using BUCHI’s Rotavapor R-210. The supplied analytical-grade solvents, such as MeOH and EtOH, were all utilized without any further purification. All the chemicals and reagents acquired from Sigma Aldrich Chemicals Company (USA), TCI (India) Pvt. Ltd., Merck (India), and/or Spectrochem (India) were utilized as received. Deuterated solvents CDCl3 and DMSO-d 6 were used to record the NMR spectrum of the synthesized compounds. Ligand (tmtp) was synthesized following our previously reported procedure [21]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the Gaussian 16 B.01 suite of programs [37]. Geometry optimizations were performed at the ωB97X-D/def2-SVP level of theory [38,39]. 4.2 Instrumentation Nuclear magnetic resonance spectra were recorded on a JEOL ECS-400 spectrometer operating at 400 MHz for 1H NMR and 101 MHz for 13C{1 H} NMR respectively. Tetramethyl silane (TMS) (0.00 ppm) was used as a reference internal solvent to record the 1H and 13C{1H} NMR spectra for all the compounds. During analysis of the 1H NMR spectra, the proton peak for CDCl3 was fixed at 7.246 ppm and the carbon peak was fixed at 77.0 ppm. The 1H NMR patterns of chemical shifts were characterized in parts per million (ppm). The terms singlet (s), doublet (d), doublet of doublet (dd), triplet (t), and multiplet (m) were used to describe the peak splitting patterns. The coupling constant (J) values are given in Hertz (Hz). A Xevo G2-SQ-Tof (Waters, USA) was used to examine the high-resolution electron impact mass spectra (HR-EIMS), which are compatible with ACQUITY UPLCs and nano ACQUITY UPLCs systems. The melting points of the ligand and the complex were determined using an analog melting point apparatus. 4.3 Synthesis of [Ni(tmtp)2](NO3)2 For the synthesis of Ni(II) complex of ligand [tmtp], a 1:2 reaction between nickel nitrate and the ligand was formulated. Accordingly, a solution of [tmtp] (0.532 g, 2 mmol) was prepared in acetonitrile (2 mL) in a 10 mL round bottom flask and a nickel nitrate (0.290 g, 1 mmol) solution in acetonitrile (1 mL) was mixed while keeping the solution in constant stirring. Within seconds, the green solution turns into a turbid light bluish solution. The reaction mixture was allowed to stir for an additional 1 h at room temperature. On completion of the reaction, the light-bluish solid was separated using Whatman’s filter paper. A light bluish solid was obtained as an analytically pure compound. Yield: 63 % (0.449 g). Mp: 232-234 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6 ) δ 8.85 (s, 2H), 8.51(s, 2H), 8.03 (s, 4H), 7.46 (s, 2H), 7.08 – 6.86 (m, 8H), 5.12 (s, 4H), 2.13 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 156.0, 149.3, 148.7, 140.4, 130.1, 129.9, 124.6, 121.9 115.2, 114.9, 114.0, 61.0, 20.3. HRMS (ESI+) m/z calcd. for [M-2NO3 -]2+ = 295.0839; found 295.0838. IR υmax (cm-1): 3136 (m, Csp2-H stretch.), 3106 (m, triazole), 1609 (s, C=C stretch.), 1463(s, C-H methylene bending), 1292 (s, Csp3-O stretch.), 779 (s, C=Csp2 bend.). Elemental analysis for C30H28N10NiO8: found: C, 49.80; H, 3.69; N, 19.20; Calculated: C, 50.37; H, 3.95; N, 19.58. 4.4 Mercury drop experiment To establish whether Ni(II) complex 1 exhibits heterogeneity or homogeneity in the SM cross-coupling coupling reaction, a mercury drop experiment was performed. In this test, a reaction vessel was charged with 0.5 mmol of aryl halide, 0.6 mmol of phenyl boronic acid, 3 equiv. of K2CO3, and 2.0 mol % of catalyst 1, along with 1 mL of toluene and a catalytic amount (0.15 mL) of water. A drop of mercury was then added to the reaction mixture, which was stirred at 100 °C for 7 h. We observed no impact on the yield of the biaryl product, indicating that Hg (0) does not influence the catalysis. 4.5 Radical trapping experiment In this experiment, a reaction vessel was prepared with 0.5 mmol of aryl halide, 0.6 mmol of phenyl boronic acid, 3 equivalents of K₂CO₃, 0.5 mmol of TEMPO, and 2.0 mol% of Ni(II) complex. The mixture also included 1 mL of toluene and a catalytic amount of water (0.15 mL) and was stirred at 100 °C for 7 h. After the reaction, 30 mL of water was added to the mixture, and the aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 10 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (20 mL), dried over MgSO₄, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. Notably, the reaction was unaffected by the addition of 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinoxyl (TEMPO), yielding the biaryl product 4Aa in a satisfactory yield of 77 %. 4.6 General catalytic protocol for the synthesis of biaryls Aryl halides (2A-P) (0.5 mmol) and different phenyl boronic acids (3a-f) (0.6 mmol) were charged with 1 (2 mol%) and K2CO3 (1 mmol) in a reaction tube. 1.15 mL of a toluene/H2O (1:0.15) solvent mixture was added into the reaction tubed and heated at 100 °C for 7 h. After the reaction was complete, the mixture was cooled, and the work-up was performed using H2O (15 mL) and ethyl acetate (3 × 20 mL). The combined organic layers were dried with anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude residue obtained was further purified by column chromatography on silica gel (230-400 mesh) using hexane: ethyl acetate (99:1) as the eluting solvent. The biaryl coupling products [4Aa-4Na, 4Bb-4Bd, 4De-4Df, 4Fb-4Ff, 4Oe, 4Pf] and [4Aa, 4Ba, 4Da, 4Ga, 4Fa, 4La] were isolated in 46–63 % with aryl chlorides while 81–94 % with aryl bromides. coredata.dc:description: In this report, we present an enhanced Suzuki-Miyaura (SM) cross-coupling reaction catalyzed by a Ni(II) complex coordinated with a N-bound triazolyl-pyridine (tmtp) ligand featuring a pendant tolyloxymethyl group. The N-bound triazolyl-pyridine ligand is chosen for its distinct electronic properties compared to structurally similar "C-bound" triazolyl-pyridine and bipyridyl ligands. The newly synthesized square-planar, diamagnetic nickel complex [Ni(tmtp)2](NO3)2 (1) has been thoroughly characterized using various spectroscopic and spectrometry techniques including 2-D NMR. The developed methodology requires only 2 mol% of catalyst loading and is applicable for aryl-iodide, -chlorides and –bromides. ESI-MS (+) analysis of the reaction mixture at different time intervals revealed the provable catalytic cycle via Ni(0)/Ni(II).
